You have slain an enemy!

For all who don't know API: An API is a software intermediary that makes it possible for application programs to interact with each other and share data. It's often an implementation of REST that exposes a specific software functionality while protecting the rest of the application.
I'm still kind of lost here, so it's a program that exposes Riot's software/game, but still makes it safe and usable?

The Match History is basically what the API provides.

So rather than building a program that reads everything off of the Match History page (and updating that program when the layout of the match history changes), Riot made an API so programmers can just ask Riot and get the information in a way that's easy to use in programming. Programmers can then go and do fun stuff with that data, like tell you your win rate with a certain champion or with certain friends.

It doesn't interact with the game, just the history.
You. I signed in to rate yours higher. You actually explained it. I like you.
{{champion:81}} agreed

Thank you, that's all I needed to know.  I was really hoping to write an iOS that was interactive with the game.. But now I am going to look into interfacing the match history, etc.  

Up voted
You were going to write an iOS app but you didn't know what API is? lol ok

Different games have different types API's. Riot could have made a spectator API, which would be usable in 8bitbyte's idea. Riot could have also made a mod API, which would have let us design our own custom game modes. Instead, Riot chose to focus on the history of matches being available via the API. 

Items and Champion info is also available via the API, so it's not completely limited to Match History, but Match History is the end use case that people are most familiar with. 

You'll also notice that 8bitbyte never said they didn't know what an API is, they implied they didn't know what was in the Riot API.

In layman's terms, API stands for Application Programming Interface.
It's what websites usually use to interact with various databases. In this case, an API would be used to communicate with Riot's servers to retrieve information and output it in an understandable manner to individuals such as you and I.

EDIT: (And yes, while keeping your information safe.)

For example,
Many websites use API's to attach things like Twitter feeds and such to their websites.
Similarly, you could use the Google Map's API to program your own personal distance calculator, or something.
